p: Two key components of the ZIKV response by governments and health agencies are (1) vector control and (2) preventing infection in pregnant women. The WHO’s ZIKV operational response plan includes control of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes and financing contraceptive services in affected areas to manage pregnancy and mitigate the impact of ZIKV [ 4]. At the CDC’s April 2016 Zika Action Plan Summit, the CDC Director acknowledged “the control of Aedes aegypti is challenging” and declared that decreasing the risk of ZIKV to pregnant women and women of childbearing age is a key priority [ 13].
